newsitem.title: USA: U.S. govt requests further waiver on Helms-Burton.
newsitem.headline: U.S. govt requests further waiver on Helms-Burton.

text.p: U.S. President Bill Clinton has decided to waive for another six months part of the Helms-Burton law which toughens Washington's embargo against Cuba, the State Department announced on Wednesday.
The waiver, the third, relates to the right of U.S. citizens to sue foreign companies that utilize property in Cuba confiscated by the communist government there.
"The president again has decided to suspend the right to file suit under Title Three (of the law) for an additional six months," assistant secretary of state Stuart Eizenstat told a news conference.
Eizenstat said an administration effort to persuade allies in Europe and Latin America to take a tougher line on Cuba's human rights record had been paying off over the past six months.
"The president would expect to continue to suspend (Title Three) so long as our allies are stepping up their activity in support of democracy in Cuba," he said.

While suspending Title Three, the administration has enforced another section of the act which denies U.S. visas to senior executives of foreign companies deemed to have "trafficked" in confiscated property in Cuba.
